features being common to all, whilst their differences are only of specific
value. His <u>Orbiculina complanata</u> (really <u>Orbiculites marginalis</u>)
he characterises by its spiral commencement, and its possessing
only one layer of cells; his <u>O Tonga</u> (Marginopora) he characterises
by its cyclical commencement, and by its possessing of two
superficial layers of cells, with an intermediate stratum as
I had previously pointed out; whilst the <u>O.adunca</u> he shows
to commence on the spiral type, and to carry it on much further than his O. complanata, but finally to assume the
cyclical and then to correspond very closely with his <u>O Tonga</u>
The title of the genus <u>Orbitolites</u> to a place in the group of
Foraminifera; in near proximity <s>with</s> to, if not in union with,
<u>Orbiculina</u> (which had been ranked as such by M. D'Orbigny
from an early period of his investigations),and the entire absence
its claim to be ranked among the Bryozoa (Polyzoa), were
clearly established by Prof. Williamson in his valuable
memoir; and though I shall hereafter have occasion
